case_name: H.E.H. the Nizams Religious Endowment Trust

facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 491, 492 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal Nos. 491, 492 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 14, 1962 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Case Referred No. 4 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 14, 1962 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Case Referred No. 4 of 1961.

facts.text: By an indenture dated September 14, 1950, H.E.H. the Nizam of Hyderabad created a trust known as H.E.H. the Nizams Religious Endowment Trust.

anchor.surface_text: By an indenture dated September 14, 1950, H.E.H. the Nizam of Hyderabad created a trust known as H.E.H. the Nizams Religious Endowment Trust, hereinafter referred to as the Trust, under which he settled certain securities of the face value of Rs. 40 lakhs

facts.text: Settled certain securities of the face value of Rs. 40 lakhs for implementing the objects described in the Trust deed.

anchor.surface_text: under which he settled certain securities of the face value of Rs. 40 lakhs for implementing the objects described in the Trust deed.

facts.text: Under the Trust deed three trustees were appointed, including the settlor.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Trust deed three trustees were appointed, including the settlor.

facts.text: During the life-time of the Settlor the balance of the income shall be accumulated and shall be added to the corpus of the Trust Fund.

anchor.surface_text: During the life-time of the Settlor the balance of the income shall be accumulated and shall be added to the corpus of the Trust Fund.

facts.text: On and after the death of the Settlor the Trustees shall hold the accumulated corpus of the Trust Fund upon trust to spend the income thereof for any one or more of the following religious or charitable objects.

anchor.surface_text: On and after the death of the Settlor the Trustees shall hold the accumulated corpus of the Trust Fund upon trust to spend the income thereof for any one or more of the following religious or charitable objects in such shares

facts.text: Two of the said objects were for religious and charitable purposes within the taxable territories and the other two for purposes outside the taxable territories.

anchor.surface_text: Two of the said objects were for religious and charitable purposes within the taxable territories and the other two for purposes outside the taxable territories.

facts.text: Under the deed no power was conferred on the trustees during the life time of the settlor to set apart and allocate the accumulated income or a part of it from the Trust properties for any one or more of the objects mentioned therein.

anchor.surface_text: It is important to notice that under the deed no power was conferred on the trustees during the life time of the settlor to set apart and allocate the accumulated income or a part of it from the Trust properties for any one or more of the objects

facts.text: The said settlor is still alive.

anchor.surface_text: The said settlor is still alive.

facts.text: For the assessment years 1952-53 and 1953-54 the Trustees were assessed to income-tax on the income during the relevant previous years arising from the said Trust property.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment years 1952-53 and 1953-54 the Trustees were assessed to income-tax on the income during the relevant previous years arising from the said Trust property.

facts.text: The Trustees claimed exemption under S. 4(3)(i) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Trustees claimed exemption under S. 4(3)(i) of the Act.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer, on appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, and on further appeals the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Hyderabad, concurrently held that the assessee was not entitled to the exemption under the said section.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, on appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, and on further appeals the Income- tax Appellate Tribunal, Hyderabad, concurrently held that the assessee was not entitled to the exemption under the said section.

facts.text: At the instance of the assessee, the following question was referred to the High Court under s. 66(1) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the assessee, the following question was referred to the High Court under s. 66(1) of the Act

facts.text: A Division Bench of the Andhra Pradesh High Court, Hyderabad, consisting of Seshachelapati and Venkatesam, JJ, held that the Trust was not entitled to the exemption.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the Andhra Pradesh High Court, Hyderabad, consisting of Seshachelapati and Venkatesam, JJ, on a consideration of the relevant provisions of the deed and the Act, came to the conclusion that on the terms of S. 4(3)(i) of the Act, the Trust was not entitled to the exemption.

facts.text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Subba Rao, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Subba Rao, J.

facts.text: Narsaraju, Anwarullah Pasha, J. B. Dadachanji, O. C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain, for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Narsaraju, Anwarullah Pasha, J. B. Dadachanji, O. C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain, for the appellant.

facts.text: V. Viswanatha Sastri, N. D. Karkhanis, R. H. Dhebar and N. Sachthey, for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: V. Viswanatha Sastri, N. D. Karkhanis, R. H. Dhebar and N. Sachthey, for the respondent.

facts.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

facts.text: Trustees had not exercised option to apply income to religious or charitable purposes without the taxable territories.

anchor.surface_text: that proviso (a) to S. 4(3)(i) of the Act would be attracted ,only when the Trustees exercised their option to apply the income to religious or charitable purposes without the taxable territories, that in the present case the Trustees had not exercised the said option

facts.text: No setting apart of the income for the said purposes by Trustees.

anchor.surface_text: as in the present ,case admittedly there was no setting apart of the income for the said purposes, the assessee could not claim any exemption thereunder.

facts.text: Income was being accumulated without setting apart for purposes mentioned in the Trust deed.

anchor.surface_text: As the income was being accumulated by the Trustees, the argument proceeded, without setting apart the whole or any part thereof for one or other of the purposes mentioned in the Trust deed

facts.text: Clause 3(d)(v) of the Trust deed is only an expression of desire on the part of the settlor that the income should be spent equally on the four purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 3(d)(v) of the Trust deed on which reliance is placed is only an expression of desire on the part of the settlor that the income of the Trust should be spent equally on the four religious and charitable purposes mentioned in the deed.

facts.text: Trustees have no power to set apart or accumulate the income for any of the purposes till after the death of the settlor.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, cl. 3(d) of the Trust deed indicates that the Trustees have no power to set apart or accumulate the income for any of the purposes mentioned in the Trust deed till after the death of the settlor.

holdings.text: The Trust was not entitled to the exemption under S. 4(3)(i) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons we hold that the answer given by the High Court to the question referred to it by the Income- tax Appellate Tribunal is correct. The appeals fail

holdings.reasoning_summary: Income accumulated during settlor's lifetime not applied or finally set apart for religious/charitable purposes within taxable territories; trustees lacked power to allocate; mere desire in deed insufficient; akin to mixed purposes trust pending selection.

holdings.text: Under S. 4(3)(i), income from property held wholly or in part under trust for religious/charitable purposes is exempt only if applied or finally set apart/consciously accumulated for such purposes within taxable territories.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, manifest that under cl. i , only income from the property wholly or in part held in trust actually applied or set apart for application for future spending on religious or charitable purposes within the taxable territories is exempted

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual comparison of clause parts; 'applied' means spent, 'accumulated/set apart' means conscious earmarking; legislative history restricts post-1953 to within territories; burden on assessee.

holdings.text: The proviso to S. 4(3)(i) operates only when income is applied to religious/charitable purposes outside taxable territories.

anchor.surface_text: The proviso to cl. excepts the two classes of income subject to the condition mentioned therein from the operation of the substantive clause. It comes into operation only when the said income is applied to religious

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary rules of construction for provisos (Craies); proviso qualifies substantive clause only on specified condition of outside application; does not alter substantive requirement.

holdings.text: Accumulated income not exempt as it was held in suspense with option to trustees for inside/outside purposes, akin to mixed purposes trust until selection/set apart.

anchor.surface_text: the argument of Mr. Narasa Raju, namely, that as at the time the income was accumulated the Trustees did not exercise the option, the accumulation would necessarily be for some of the purposes within

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects automatic attribution to inside purposes; option keeps income unallocated; analogy to JC in Mohammad Ibrahim Riza where mixed/optional purposes require specific set apart.

holdings.text: Clause 3(d)(v) of Trust deed is only expression of settlor's desire, not amounting to setting apart by trustees.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 3 d v of the Trust deed on which reliance is placed is only an expression of desire on the part of the settlor that the income of the Trust should be spent equally on the four religious

holdings.reasoning_summary: Desire does not equate to trustees' conscious act of allocation; never raised as fact earlier.

holdings.text: Trustees have no power under deed to set apart or accumulate income for purposes until after settlor's death.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, cl. 3 d of the Trust deed indicates that the Trustees have no power to set apart or accumulate the income for any of the purposes mentioned in the Trust deed till after the death

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct from deed terms; accumulation during life added to corpus without allocation.

holdings.text: Onus of showing entitlement to tax exemption lies on assessee; case must clearly fall within provision.

anchor.surface_text: It is settled law that the burden is on the Revenue authorities to show that the income is liable, to tax under the statute but the onus of showing that a particular class of income

holdings.reasoning_summary: Settled law; assessee failed to prove set apart.

holdings.text: Trustees did not set apart accumulated income for purposes within taxable territories.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot, therefore, hold on the material placed before us that the Trustees have set apart the accumulated income for purposes within the taxable territories.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of conscious allocation; power absent; desire insufficient.

holdings.text: Expression 'accumulated for application' requires conscious present act to set apart income for specified purpose.

anchor.surface_text: The expression accumulated for a purpose involves a conscious act in present and posits a clear indication on the part of the trustee to set apart the income for that purpose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Comparative textual analysis of clause language; uniform meaning across wholly/partial trusts.
